question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

Consider the sequence

\begin{align*}\left\{ (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\right\}\end{align*}

State whether this sequence converges or diverges, and if it converges
give its limit.
sols:
The alternating series test says that

\begin{align*}\sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n\end{align*}

converges if \emph{a\textsubscript{n}} is monotonically decreasing. In
our case, $a_n = \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)$, and since $\frac1{n}$
monotonically decreases as \emph{n} increases, and \emph{sin(x)} is a
monotone function for \emph{x} in \emph{{[}0,1{]}} we find that indeed
$a_n = \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)$ is monotonically decreasing. Hence

\begin{align*}\sum_{n=1}^\infty (-1)^n a_n\end{align*}

converges. But the question didn't ask if the series converges, but if
the sequence \emph{\{(-1)\textsuperscript{n} a\textsubscript{n}\}}
converges. This, however, follow as well because if a series
$\sum_{n=1}^\infty b_n$ converges, then the sequence
\emph{\{b\textsubscript{n}\}} must converge to zero, that is

\begin{align*}0 = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} b_n = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} (-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)\end{align*}

Hence, $(-1)^n \sin\left(\frac1{n}\right)$ converges to \emph{0}.
hints:
It might be difficult to figure out the exact values of this sequence.
Instead, try using a theorem to prove convergence or divergence.

For an alternative solution, what is the standard way to show
convergence for an alternating series?
